user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of calc_userhash:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
calc_userhash (struct DigestAlgorithm *da,
               const char *username, const size_t username_len,
               const char *realm, const size_t realm_len,
               uint8_t *digest_bin)
{
  mhd_assert (NULL != username);
  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
  digest_update (da, username, username_len);
  digest_update_with_colon (da);
  digest_update (da, realm, realm_len);
  digest_calc_hash (da, digest_bin);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function calc_userhash:
#define _MHD_static_inline staticinline__attribute__((always_inline))
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
struct DigestAlgorithm
{
  /**
   * A context for the digest algorithm, already initialized to be
   * useful for @e init, @e update and @e digest.
   */
  union DigestCtx ctx;

  /**
   * The hash calculation algorithm.
   */
  enum MHD_DigestBaseAlgo algo;

  /**
   * Buffer for hex-print of the final digest.
   */
#ifdef _DEBUG
  bool uninitialised; /**< The structure has been not set-up */
  bool algo_selected; /**< The algorithm has been selected */
  bool ready_for_hashing; /**< The structure is ready to hash data */
  bool hashing; /**< Some data has been hashed, but the digest has not finalised yet */
#endif /* _DEBUG */
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only code that appears to invoke a compiler-specific language extension is the use of the GCC-style attribute(always_inline) via the _MHD_static_inline macro. Other parts of the provided code use standard C constructs: struct/union/enum declarations, size_t/uint8_t types, preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef _DEBUG), and ordinary macros (mhd_assert) and function calls. These do not constitute compiler language extensions as defined by compiler documentation, so they do not need to be investigated for Rule 1.2. (Note: identifier naming with leading underscore and uppercase is a separate concern but is not a compiler language-extension per Rule 1.2.)
